sect2.title: Contents
sect2.para: Level 1 consists of all "core" &d-i; packages, i.e. all packages with translatable material in the &d-i; development tree. These packages are used during the installation "first stage".

In &d-i; jargon, the first stage is the part of &d-i; which occurs from the initial boot up to the first (and only) reboot of the system. All user interactions screens shown to users during this stage are part of the first level for l10n.
Some material (country names and keyboard maps names) are handled in non core &d-i; packages. This material will be part of the level 2 of translations.

In order to make the translators work easy and simple, all translatable strings are assembled in a single file. Translators must work on this file and not on the various files dispersed in the &d-i; development tree (these files are automatically generated).

sect2.title: Files location and access methods
sect2.para: Translators should remember that using SVN is strongly encouraged as this is the only way for them to commit their own translations.
To begin the translation work for level 1, translators should copy the packages/po/template.pot to &language;.po (where &language; is the ISO-639 code of the language, see ) and complete this file.

sect2.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect2.para: Translation updates should be done by direct commits to the &d-i; SVN repository (see for details about SVN use). In case this is absolutely impossible, these updates can be sent as bug reports against the debian-installer package (see for details).

sect2.title: Specific recommendations
sect2.para: The &d-i; core file uses hundreds of strings which represent the content of the screens which are or may be shown to &d-i; users during the installation process.
Several of these strings are commented with indications or hints for translators.

sect3.title: Limited length strings
sect3.para: Several strings are limited in length. This means they should not exceed 65 characters for single-width character languages and 32 characters for double-width character languages such as CJK (Chinese/Japanese/Korean) and similar languages.
This constraint may be checked by the scripts/l10n/choices-check.pl script from the &d-i; development tree:
This script will output the offending line(s) number(s) as well as the number of characters in this/these line(s).

sect3.title: "Choose language" menu entry
sect3.para: This entry is the language selection screen entry for each language. Translators can translate it but they should keep "Choose language" in English as an alternative so that users mistakenly choosing a language can still find the appropriate entry to change it back to their own language.

sect3.title: Main menu entries
sect3.para: Most &d-i; packages have a main menu entry, which is the text that appears in the &d-i; main menu to allow users to select the orresponding action.

The length of this main menu entry is limited to 58 columns, ie 58 characters for single-width languages and only 29 characters for double-width languages. These main menu entries all have a comment with Mein menu entry in the PO and POT files.

sect3.title: Variable names
sect3.para: Many places in &d-i; use variables (e.g. "${LOCALE} is currently not supported in Debian"). The variable names should not be translated and be kept inside braces prepended by the dollar sign in the translation.
This constraint is checked by the spell checking scripts which report these errors separately (see for details about the spell checking scripts).
Advanced translation software such as kbabel are able to visually display such errors and warn about them before saving files.

sect3.title: Choices entries
sect3.para: Several entries in PO files are unsplitted choices list such as:

informalexample.screen: #. Type: select #. Choices #: ../netcfg-common.templates:124 msgid "Infrastructure (Managed) network, Ad-hoc network (Peer to peer)" msgstr ""

informalexample.para: For these translations, translators should take care of separating all choices with a normal comma sign, even if commas are not used in their language. Only standard commas should be used and not special commans such as those used by the Arabic language.
Commas should not be used inside individual choices.
Such errors are detected by the spellchecker scripts (see ).

sect3.title: Default mirror country
sect3.para: A special string from the choose-mirror package is intended to setup the default Debian archive mirror country, depending on the language. Translators should put there the ISO-3166 code of the country to be used as default, most often their own country name, or the country their language is spoken in. For instance, the Brazilian Portuguese translator will use "BR" as translation there, as this is the ISO-3166 code for Brazil.
Such errors are detected by the spellchecker scripts (see ).

sect3.title: Partman entries
sect3.para: A few entries in the partman are limited to 8 symbols only. Translators must be VERY careful about not exceeding this value, otherwise, the display in the partman screens will be badly broken.
